title: Discovering Shinagawa's Two Faces
theme: Exploring Shinagawa's modern and traditional areas

messages.content: I'm fascinated by how Shinagawa seems to have two completely different sides - the ultra-modern high-rises around the station and these lovely old neighborhoods I've glimpsed. Could you help me understand more about this area?

You've noticed something really interesting! Shinagawa was historically the first post station on the Tokaido road to Kyoto, and you can still find traces of that history in areas like Kitashinagawa. Meanwhile, the station area has developed into one of Tokyo's major business hubs. Would you like to explore both aspects?
Yes, I'd love to understand both sides! Could you tell me more about this post station history? And are there still places where you can see evidence of that era?

The old Tokaido area is wonderfully preserved! You can walk the historic street where travelers once stayed in inns, and visit Tokaido Museum to see Edo-period artifacts. There's also Honsenji Temple, which served travelers, and several traditional shops that have been operating for generations. Would you like a walking route through these historic spots?
That would be great! Are there any traditional restaurants or shops from that era that are still running? I'd love to experience something with real historical connection.

Yes! 'Kamasada' is a traditional restaurant that's been serving soba since the Edo period - they still make noodles by hand using traditional methods. There's also 'Yabusoba', another historic restaurant, and several traditional wagashi (sweet) shops that supplied travelers centuries ago. Would you like to know their specialties?
Yes please! And what about the modern side? How did it develop into such a business district?

The transformation began in the 1980s when Shinagawa was chosen for redevelopment due to its excellent transportation links. The area around the station was transformed with skyscrapers housing major corporations. The InterCity complex is particularly interesting - it was designed to create a 'city within a city'. Would you like to explore the modern architecture?
That would be interesting! Are there any good viewpoints to see how the old and new parts of Shinagawa interact? And are there places where you can really see the contrast?

The Sky Lounge in Shinagawa Season Terrace offers amazing views - you can see both the modern skyline and the old shitamachi areas. There's also a walking path from the station to Kitashinagawa where you literally transition from modern to traditional in about 15 minutes. Would you like a photography route that captures these contrasts?
Yes, that would be perfect! Are there any local festivals or events that celebrate either the historical or modern aspects of the area?

The Shinagawa Shukuba Matsuri in September recreates the atmosphere of the old post town, with people in period costumes and traditional performances. There's also the modern Shinagawa Inter-City Jazz Festival in summer, held among the skyscrapers. The area really embraces both identities. Would you like the festival schedule?
That sounds wonderful! What about the local community? How do people live with this mix of old and new?

It's fascinating - many residents in the old areas maintain traditional community ties, with local shopping streets and neighborhood festivals, while the business district has created its own modern community with rooftop gardens, art installations, and contemporary events. Some restaurants even cater to both office workers and local residents. Would you like to experience both communities?
Yes, I'd love that! Are there any hidden spots that show this blend of old and new particularly well?

Check out the Gotenyama Garden - it's a traditional Japanese garden surrounded by modern buildings, perfectly symbolizing this blend. There's also Musashi-Koyama Shopping Street, which maintains its traditional shopping arcade feel while incorporating modern elements. The area around Ebara Shrine is another great example, with contemporary cafes in traditional buildings. Would you like a guided tour of these spots?
